'Stearyl alcohol' (also known as octadecyl alcohol or 1-octadecanol) is an
organic compound with the formula
CH 3(CH 2) 16 CH 2OH. It is classified as
a fatty alcohol. It takes the form of white granules or flakes, which are
insoluble in water. It has a wide range of uses as an ingredient in lubricants,
resins, perfumes and cosmetics. It is used as an emollient, emulsifier, and
thickener in ointments of various sorts, and is widely used as a hair coating in
shampoos and hair conditioners.

Stearyl alcohol is prepared from stearic acid or some fats by the process of
catalytic hydrogenation. It has low toxicity. Klaus Noweck,
Wolfgang Grafahrend, "Fatty Alcohols" in Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial
Chemistry 2006, Wiley-VCH, Weinheim.
